text.p: The following are some of the leading stories in Finnish papers this morning.
HELSINGIN SANOMAT
- Valmet may win a large U.S. recycled newsprint machinery order.
- Two Finnish police officers charged with provoking 20-year-old to buy hashish.
- Some goods crossing the tax border between Finland's Aland islands and the rest of the European Union may be taxed twice from March. @
- Final report about the 1994 Estonia disaster delayed again to April, earlier expected in March, investigating committee head Kari Lehtola says.
- Finnish farmers' income has fallen 1.1 billion markka since Finland joined the EU to 6.7 billion markka last year, farmers' economic reasearch institute says.
- Estonia house only place in New York serving Finnish food without advance orders. @
KAUPPALEHTI
- EU agreement with Russia to cap steel trade is good news for the Finnish steel industry, says Sirpa Smolsky, head of the steel producers' lobby.
- Stamp duty favours foreign banks and distorts competition, Finnish banks say.
- Companies' interest in raising money from debt market has increased with falling yields but there is still virtually no secondary corporate bond market, experts say. @
- Finland in the centre of the Nordic area in plans for a European natural gas pipeline network.
HUFVUDSTADSBLADET
- Conflicts in the Social Democratic Party which leads the government are worrying, says opposition leader Esko Aho, chairman of the Centre Party.
- Growing market for pirate video recordings and compact discs is a threat to the legal domestic market.
AAMULEHTI
- Countries left outside NATO after the Madrid summit in July will get another chance, says information chief Jamie Shea. @
- All jobless Finns to be interviewed this spring for information to be put on a database for prospective employers.
TURUN SANOMAT
- Knives and Koskenkorva vodka no longer part of Swedes' perception of Finns, which has improved so much it is almost flattering, survey shows.
DEMARI
- Foreign Minister Tarja Halonen concerned that Finland may be left on the sidelines while Russia modernises its relations with NATO; says a grey zone should not be created in Europe.
-- Helsinki Newsroom +358-9-680 50 242
